Award.AwardTitle: STTR Phase I: A Direct Lithium-Ion Battery Recycling Process Yielding Battery-Grade Cathode Materials
Award.AbstractNarration:
This Small Business Technology Transfer Phase I project advances a cost-effective and scalable direct recycling method for producing battery-grade cathode materials from end-of-life (EOL) lithium-ion batteries. The commercialization of the proposed direct lithium-ion battery recycling technology will lower the energy consumption and emissions associated with battery production, reduce demand for raw battery materials and decrease lithium-ion battery manufacturing cost. Using directly recycled materials instead of raw battery materials will diminish or even avoid the negative environmental impacts from mining and processing ores and from disposal of hazardous waste. Reducing battery cost will facilitate the implementation of more efficient electrified vehicles, thus reducing petroleum demand and vehicle emissions. Finally, research on the end-of-life lithium-ion battery cathode, on the direct recycling process and on the recycled materials will advance the understanding of intercalation chemistry in nonaqueous and aqueous media and of electrode degradation during electrochemical cycling.

The intellectual merit of this project is to advance the direct recycling technology through the design and demonstration of a scalable electrochemical flow system capable of non-destructive relithiation and the optimization of post treatment operation for the recovered materials. The electrochemical flow system is capable of restoring the lost lithium in the EOL cathode material at any state of charge (SOC) and can be scaled to a commercially viable size. The cathode materials recovered in the proposed direct recycling process retain the same structure and morphology and exhibit equivalent electrochemical performance compared to the commercial virgin cathode materials. The recovery of high-value cathode materials substantially improves the profitability of lithium-ion battery recycling and is a key element of the business plan.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The NSF STTR Phase I project advances a cost-effective and scalable method for directly recycling end of life (EOL) lithium ion battery (LIB) waste yielding battery-grade cathode materials for reuse in new LIBs. The project established the viability of several thermochemical and electrochemical treatment approaches to relithiate and restore the structure, morphology, and electrochemical performance of EOL LIB cathode materials. The regenerated cathode materials show equivalent or superior electrochemical performance to commercial virgin counterparts. The viability of such a process is key to developing a direct recycling method that does not require time-consuming and energy intensive degradation and re-synthesis procedures for cathode materials such as those used in incumbent recycling methods.

The project findings have made an impact on advancing the knowledge in the field of materials science and electrochemistry. Characterizations of the end-of-life LIB cathode materials and the recycled materials contributes to the understanding of electrode materials degradation during electrochemical cycling and the conditions under which regeneration of materials can be optimized to restore the material structure, morphology, and properties. The findings from our study of electrochemical relithiation advance the understanding of intercalation materials chemistry and electrochemistry in nonaqueous and aqueous media. This project also contributes to the development of a cost-effective and scalable direct recycling method for producing battery-grade cathode materials from EOL LIBs. Incumbent recycling processes for LIBs take an indirect approach in which the most costly cathode materials are broken down into elemental constituents, thus losing much of their resale value. Our studies have shown that direct end of life rejuvenation of materials is possible, and recycling processes in other fields can use this information as a basis for directly recycling other end of life materials to increase value of the recycling process and decrease cost, energy usage, and waste.

The project findings alleviate the key technical risks of the cathode material regeneration process and address critical needs in the commercialization of direct LIB recycling technology. The commercialization of the proposed direct LIB recycling technology lowers the energy consumption and emissions associated with battery production, reduces demand for raw battery materials, and decreases LIB manufacturing cost. Using directly recycled materials instead of raw battery materials will significantly diminish the negative environmental impacts from mining and processing ores and from disposal of hazardous waste. Reducing battery cost will facilitate the implementation of more efficient electrified vehicles, thus reducing petroleum demand and vehicle emissions. The increased value of recycling batteries from this direct recycling process will help to incentivize recycling of LIBs, reduce the reliance of LIB production on the mining of expensive virgin metals (e.g., cobalt), and create a local supply of LIB materials to ensure sustainability of battery manufacturing.
